48.heading: Orson.
48.title: Fear Nothing. vol. 1
48.author: written by Dean Koontz ; adapted by Grant Alter & Derek Ruiz ; artwork by Robert Gill ; coloring by Mohan ; lettering & design by Bill Tortolini.
notes: Summary (from publisher's website via SkyRiver): "Christopher Snow is different from all those who live in Moonlight Bay California, different from anyone you've ever met. For Christopher Snow was born with a rare genetic disorder he shares with only one thousand other Americans, a disorder that leaves him extremely vulnerable to the light; a light-sensitivity so severe that he cannot leave his house in daylight, cannot enter a normally-lit room, and cannot sit at a computer. His life is filled with the fascinating rituals of one who must embrace the darkness. Only at night that he is truly free. And on one such night Chris witnesses a murder

a murder only he can solve. For Chris Snow and all the inhabitants of Moonlight Bay, terrible change is on its way; a change of potentially catastrophic proportions. But as one forced to live in the shadows, Chris Snow knows the night world better than the dark adversaries that stalk his quiet town. And along with his exceptional dog Orson, and his friends, Snow will challenge those who try to take away the only home he knows. When you live in the darkness of Moonlight Bay as Christopher Snow does, and you are desperately trying to save the day, you learn to Fear Nothing!"

128.heading: Orthodox Jews.

128.author: by Art Spiegelman
128.appears_in: cover of The New Yorker, v. 76, no. 39 (Dec. 18, 2000).
notes: Summary: A Santa and an orthodox Jew pass on the street.

129.heading: Orthodox Thought.
129.title: "Kabir : He Spoke of Tolerance and Mercy"
129.author: script, Dolly Rizvi ; illustrations, Umesh Burande ; editor, Anant Pai
129.appears_in: p. 1-31 in Amar Chitra Katha, no. 623 (1974, 2010 printing).
notes: "He rebelled against the established institution of religion, He spoke strongly against blind faith and ritualism. Kabir, who belonged to neither Hindu god nor Muslum wrote his couplets urging people to rise against orthodox thought. Kabir's words can still iron out religious differences between communities and destroy pointless pride. Everyone, he said, is equal and all gods are one. So difficult was this for the people of his time to understand that some of them resolved to be rid of him."

145.heading: Ortiz, Axel.
145.title: Crying Macho Man Presents Macho and the Gang
145.author: by José Cabrera ; art, José Cabrera ; color, Axel Ortiz.
notes: "Follow Macho, Goya, his trusty fighting cock, and Berto as they get into hot water with a cast of baddies that includes warty witches, gunky ghosts, delicious drug dealers and a few hundred acupuncture needles. Enjoy this first ever collection of Macho and the Gang and their zany adventures."

147.heading: Ortiz, Guillermo.
147.title: Kero Finn

149.heading: Ortiz, Joe, 1946-
149.title: Shakespeare on Golf : Wit and Wisdom from the Great Elizabethan Golfer and Poet
149.author: John Tullius and Joe Ortiz ; illustrations by Harry Trumbore.
notes: Each Shakespeare quotation is interpreted in golf terms and illustrated with a cartoon.

150.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
150.title: "Black Beaches"
150.author: by Segura & Ortiz
150.appears_in: p. 64-75 in Heavy Metal, v. 21, no. 2 (May 1997).

152.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
152.title: "Blood Brothers"
152.author: story, Bruce Jones ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Amid the rage of battle, Mears found Voper. Voper would keep the tenderfoot soldier alive, if Mears never questioned Voper's unusual methods!"

153.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
153.title: "Brothers"
153.author: story, Bill DuBay ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Packy and Cathy believed all men were brothers. Even their gentle grandpa and the terrifying mutants had been brothers once, before the Great War. Now the children wanted them to live in peace, but it was too late!"

155.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
155.title: "Children of the Spider"
155.author: by José Ortiz y Segura
155.appears_in: p. 56-65 in Heavy Metal 20 Year Special (Heavy Metal Special ; v. 11, no. 2 (Fall 1997).

157.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
157.title: "Death Snare!"
157.author: author, Rich Margopoulos ; illustrator, Jose Ortiz

158.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
158.title: "The Escape Chronicle"
158.author: story, Budd Lewis ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Kenward, Bernard B: #9993030. Spindled. Folded. Mutilated by life. Charlie: No last name. No number. Liberated. Grew vegetables. Brewed wine. And thought. It would take only two men to build a giant balloon. To sail away. To escape death by computerized boredom!"

159.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
159.title: "The Fighter"
159.author: by Segura and Ortiz
159.appears_in: p. 63-72 in Heavy Metal, v. 22, no. 2 (May 1998).

161.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
161.title: "Goodbye, Mr. Lincoln"
161.author: story, Bill DuBay ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Abe Lincoln. Collins. John Kennedy. What did these three great men have in common? A little black slave boy living in squalor. His dying wish. And a soul preserved by black magic for all eternity, seeking revenge."

162.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
162.title: "Harvey was a Sharp Cookie"
162.author: story, Bill DuBay ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "They destroyed the two things Harvey loved. His Fun Palace. And his daughter. But they reckoned without Harvey's powerful revenge!"
Contents page title: "Harvey, the Sharp Cookie."

164.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
164.title: "The Jewels of Araknid"
164.author: author, Rich Margopoulos ; illustrator, José Ortiz

165.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
165.title: Judge Dredd's Crime File
165.author: written by John Wagner, Alan Grant and Pete Milligan ; art by John Higgins, Bryan Talbot, Jose Ortiz and Ian Gibson ; cover illustration by Brian Bolland.
165.library has: v. 1. 1. Science fiction comic books, strips, etc. I. Wagner, John. II. Grant, Alan. III. Milligan, Peter. IV. Higgins, John. V. Talbot, Bryan. VI. Ortiz, Jose. VII. Gibson, Ian. a. British comics. Call no.

166.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
166.title: "The Last Chronicle"
166.author: story, Budd Lewis ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Charlie had escaped, flown away in the balloon 'Icarus,' left Bernie alone. They tried to convince Bernie it was insane fantasy. Slowly, bit by bit, they were succeeding!"

167.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
167.title: "The Leader"
167.author: by Antonio Segura and Jose Ortiz
167.appears_in: p. 34-45 in Heavy Metal, v. 17, no. 6 (Jan. 1994).

168.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
168.title: "The Little Spaceship That Could!"
168.author: author, John Ellis Sech ; illustrator, José Ortiz

169.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
169.title: "Lolita, a Very Special Girl"
169.author: by Segura & Ortiz
169.appears_in: p. 10-17 in Heavy Metal, v. 19, no. 4 (Sept. 1995).

170.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
170.title: "Man"
170.author: by Ortiz and Segura
170.appears_in: p. 84-98 in Heavy Metal, v. 11, no. 3 (Fall 1987).

172.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
172.title: Las Mil Caras de Jack el Destripador
172.author: José Ortiz, Antonio Segura.

173.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
173.title: "Mother Park"
173.author: story, Roger McKenzie ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "All he wanted to do was play and all the computerized, electronic park wanted to do was let him. The park loved him and wanted to protect him from those nasty policeman. Oh, but it's not nice to fool Mother Park!"

175.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
175.title: "Negritos y Negreros"
175.author: guión, Antonio Segura ; dibujos, José Ortiz

176.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
176.title: "A Night Full of Zombies!"
176.author: author, Rich Margopoulos ; illustrator, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Pantha fights for her life on the terrible night of the zombies!"

177.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
177.title: "The Oasis Inn"
177.author: story, Bob Toomey ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Scritch, Tokie and Ham had finally been relieved of guard detail and were on their way to the Oasis Inn. There the girls were wild and hairy. There the music was loud and crazy. There was Sergeant Crank holding Teena!"

178.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
178.title: "Once Upon a Miracle"
178.author: story, Bill DuBay, Art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Silently they gather. Demons. Trolls. Devils. The jungle fighters of Lucifer's underground. On a desperate mission to rout Heaven's angel army and severely disrupt Christmas!"

179.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
179.title: "Orem Ain't Got No Head Cheese!"
179.author: story, Bill DuBay ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Ole Orem hated what them damn hunters did to his women folk. So Orem took a fitting revenge. But that last hunter he shot. There was something awful queer 'bout his head!"
Contents page title: "Orem Got No Head Cheese."

180.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
180.title: Ozono
180.author: A
notes: Translated from Spanish to Italian. 1. Spanish comics. 2. Italian comics. 3. Adventure story comics. I. Segura, Antonio. II. Ortiz, José. III. Series. IV. Editrice Comic Art. Call no.: PN6777.S45 O916 1991

181.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
181.title: "The Pit and the Pendulum"
181.author: story adaptation, Rich Margopoulos ; art, José Ortiz
notes: At head of title: "Edgar Allan Poe's".

182.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
182.title: "Playpen of a God!"
182.author: Jose Ortiz, art
notes: "Earth was once a fair and wonderful place. Plants grew in abundance. Fair winds rustled through forest leaves. Animals romped. Men walked on straight, strong legs, like the gods!"
Data from Glenn MacKay and Martin O'Hearn via the Grand Comics Database Project.

184.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
184.title: "Purge!"
184.author: story, Bruce Bezaire ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Meet Obed Black. A cop with a mean streak. A police officer endowed with the powers of a judge, jury and executioner, sworn to rid the world of naughtiness. And Obed Black is about to have a very bad day!"

187.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
187.title: Il Serpente Piumato
187.author: soggetto e sceneggiatura, Claudio Nizzi ; disegni, Jose Ortiz ; copertina, Claudio Villa ; lettering, Renata Tuis.

188.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
188.title: "The Swallows, the Vultures, and the Bridge"
188.author: José Ortiz, Segura
188.appears_in: p. 79-90 in Heavy Metal, v. 22, no. 4 (Sept. 1998).

189.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
189.title: "Tale of a Fox"
189.author: story, Nicola Cuti ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "A tale from ancient China in which a game of double-cross does a double-take as our heroine escapes the clutches of her horrid uncle by being a foxy lady!"

190.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
190.title: "A Useless Old Man"
190.author: by Segura & Ortiz
190.appears_in: p. 20-31 in Heavy Metal, v. 19, no. 6 (Mar. 1993).

191.heading: Ortiz, José, 1932-
191.title: "Warrior on the Edge of Forever"
191.author: story, Bill DuBay ; art, Jose Ortiz
notes: "Each time they had come, the false gods, the power hungry religious leaders, we were there to defeat them. Now there is a new crisis. Therefore, again we face the ultimate evil!"
Contents page title: "Warrior on the Edge."
